awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowships in Earth and Environmental Sciences (SURFEES)
awd_abstract_narration:
This summer REU-Site program in the Schmid College of Science and Technology at Chapman University will annually provide 10-11 students selected exclusively from 2-year community colleges (focusing specifically on under-represented minorities, women, and low-income students) with the opportunity to engage in research on interdisciplinary earth and environmental topics ranging from mineral-surface interactions to wetland ecosystems to extreme global weather events. Engaging under-served students in this REU-Site program is expected to create a more diverse population of science-literate citizens to address current and future scientific challenges. Measurable outcomes include the number of community college students remaining committed to STEM majors by transferring to and graduating as science majors from 4-year institutions, REU students' increased understanding of the research process, research ethics, and the value of research contributions to local and global communities, and the number of REU-Site participants who enter graduate programs or careers in the sciences. Chapman University campus resources and local community organizations will provide professional development workshops, give presentations at a weekly speaker symposium on scientific careers and internships, and prepare participants with the skills needed to be effective and ethical science researchers.

Southern California is a highly developed urbanized area with considerable natural resources, resulting in a wide range of earth and environmental challenges and problems. Addressing these complex issues requires an interdisciplinary and educated workforce of scientists. Through participation in cutting-edge research with faculty mentors working at the forefront of their respective disciplines, students will engage in complex scientific studies on topics including the transformation pathways of pollutants, environmental impacts on intertidal ecosystems, effects of climate change on extreme weather-related events, and carbon sequestration in wetlands.  These interactions will both provide valuable interdisciplinary research experiences to a typically underserved student population and drive the principal investigators' scholarly research forward.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship in Earth and Environmental Sciences (SURFEES) program provided a total of 37 students from neighboring community colleges with intensive 8-week summer research experiences across 3 separate summer periods (2019, 2021, 2022), pausing only for one year due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Focus groups and surveys of participants demonstrated that the program achieved its key intended outcomes, specifically to:

a) Provide transformative research experiences in close collaboration with a faculty mentor to students from 2-year institutions that lack substantial research facilities or programs;

b) Increase the participation of under-represented students, particularly Hispanics, women and low-income individuals, in hands-on scientific research and increase their confidence level in conducting research;

c) Develop scientifically-literate, experienced participants who persist, transfer into and graduate with science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) baccalaureate degrees and go on to pursue graduate study and/or professions in science-related fields; and

d) Increase student awareness of earth and environmental issues, the inherent interdisciplinarity required to address them, and career opportunities in environmental areas.

Across the three years of funding provided under this award, the program achieved its goal of prioritizing students from groups and identities that are under-represented in the sciences, specifically:

-       65% of participants were from under-represented minorities

-       62% of participants were female

-       54% of participants were from low-income backgrounds

The research experiences spanned fields including biochemistry, earth system science, environmental geochemistry, food science, and physical chemistry. In addition, professional development was provided to all participants on a weekly basis throughout the summer and included sessions on writing a resume, giving public presentations, considering graduate school, and finding scholarship/fellowship opportunities.  Participants also attended weekly presentations from a variety of Chapman faculty who discussed their scholarly interests and representatives from various environmental organizations and non-profits. Additional panels on topics including women in STEM, research ethics and science careers were also scheduled for participants.

The summer research experience concluded with a formal in-person research showcase (featuring lunch, flash talks, and poster presentations) which was attended by SURFEES and other summer research fellows, SURFEES mentors, Chapman University faculty and administrators, participants’ families, and representatives from the community colleges.
